docs.lead_paragraph: Columbia University agreed yesterday to pay $5.1 million to settle a civil complaint that it billed the state Medicaid program for obstetrical services that Columbia doctors did not provide. The settlement resolves a lawsuit brought by federal prosecutors accusing the university of billing the government for birthing services that were actually performed by midwives, residents and other doctors who were not eligible for Medicaid reimbursement.

headline.main: Columbia Settles Suit on Billing Practices

docs.abstract: Columbia University agrees to pay $5.1 million to settle civil suit alleging it billed New York Medicaid program for birthing services that Columbia doctors did not provide; midwives, residents and other doctors at Allen Pavilion, community hospital operated by New York Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University, performed services; Columbia admits to no wrong-doing in settlement (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Newborn's One-Night Stay Said to Pose No Danger'' (news article, Dec. 19):

docs.lead_paragraph: Asia is expected to be the site of the next AIDS explosion. Yet at a United Nations population conference in Bangkok this week the American delegation tried to block an endorsement of condom use to prevent AIDS. It's not often that a vote is taken at a U.N. meeting, where consensus is usually the goal. But this time participants voted -- and the other nations united in striking down the American position. By now, embarrassing behavior by the Bush administration at international meetings on women, health and the environment has become almost routine. The consequences, however, go beyond resentment and ridicule. Mr. Bush has concluded that family planning and sex education abroad -- including AIDS education -- can be sacrificed to please the far right without angering Americans who want to keep abortion legal here. Assistant Secretary of State Gene Dewey said in Bangkok that the U.S. ''supports the sanctity of life from conception to natural death,'' a statement, we suspect, the administration would not dare make with the cameras rolling at home.
docs.abstract: Editorial deplores attempt by American delegation to UN conference on population to block endorsement of condom use to prevent AIDS and to strike down references in conference's document to 'reproductive rights' and 'reproductive health services,' as these can include abortion and abortion counseling; says Asia is expected to be site of next AIDS explosion, and teenage girls are particularly at risk

docs.lead_paragraph: A baby girl born infected with the West Nile virus in Syracuse a month ago is the world's first documented case in which the virus was transmitted in the womb, health officials said yesterday. The baby was born with severe brain defects and is being treated for a respiratory infection in a hospital, said Dr. Lloyd F. Novick, the Commissioner of the Onondaga County Health Department in Syracuse. West Nile infection was diagnosed in the baby's 20-year-old mother before the baby was born.

headline.main: Transmission Of West Nile In the Womb Is Confirmed

docs.abstract: Health officials say baby girl born infected with West Nile virus in Syracuse month ago is world's first documented case in which virus was transmitted in womb; baby's mother was diagnosed as having West Nile virus before baby was born; baby has severe brain defects; federal health officials emphasize that they could document baby's infection with virus but could not prove that it caused her brain damage; Centers for Disease Control and Infection says it does not advise doctors to use blood tests to screen pregnant women for West Nile virus, in part because no specific treatment exists for it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Police officials here said today that they were investigating the death of a newborn whose body was discovered after the baby's 17-year-old mother went to Stamford Hospital to be treated for complications related to childbirth. As of tonight, no charges had been brought in the case, but police officials said the investigation was continuing. Both the young woman, who is a senior at Stamford High School, and her 20-year-old boyfriend, who also lives in Stamford, have retained defense lawyers.

headline.main: Police Await Autopsy Results In Stamford Newborn's Death

docs.abstract: Police officials in Stamford, Conn, await result of autopsy on newborn whose body was discovered after baby's 17-year-old mother went to hospital to be treated for complications related to childbirth; baby's body was found buried in boyfriend's backyard; no names are released (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Deliveries that send new mothers home from the hospital after one night do not seriously endanger newborns despite the many state laws that restrict the practice, a study to be published on Thursday says. Regardless of whether they had long or short stays, infants were later sent to the emergency room or readmitted to the hospital at the same rate, according to the study, by researchers from the Harvard Medical School.

headline.main: Newborn's One-Night Stay Said to Pose No Danger

docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School study finds that deliveries that send new mothers home from hospital after one night do not seriously endanger newborns despite the many state laws that restrict practice; study shows that regardless of whether they had long or short stays, infants were later sent to emergency room or readmitted to hospital at same rate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The percentage of babies born prematurely in the United States reached a 20-year high last year, driven by an increase in twins and triplets. The government also found a rise in prenatal care and a drop in smoking during pregnancy. Births to teenagers fell for the 10th year in a row, with abortions declining, too. At the same time, births to women in their 30's and 40's continued to climb steadily, according to an annual review of birth statistics released today. Over all, 4,025,933 babies were born in the United States in 2001, a small drop from 2000.

headline.main: Surge in Multiple Births Produces Record in Premature Babies

docs.abstract: Percentage of babies born prematurely in United States reaches 20-year high last year, nearly 12 percent, driven by increase in twins and triplets; government also finds rise in prenatal care and drop in smoking during pregnancy; births to teenagers fell for 10th year in row (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush named Thomas H. Kean, a former Republican governor of New Jersey, to replace Henry A. Kissinger as chairman of an independent commission to investigate the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Kean, a political moderate who served on White House commissions in the Clinton administration and is the president of Drew University in New Jersey, said he did not believe he faced the potential business conflicts that led Mr. Kissinger to abruptly withdraw last week as chairman.

headline.main: Bush Names Former New Jersey Governor to 9/11 Panel

docs.abstract: Pres Bush names Thomas H Kean, former Republican governor of New Jersey, chairman of independent commission to investigate Sept 11 attacks; Kean says he does not believe he faces potential business conflicts that led Henry Kissinger to abruptly withdraw as chairman; Bush lauds Kean as 'leader respected for integrity, fairness and good judgment'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past few weeks, we've been treated to a familiar spectacle: scientists trying to nudge one another out of the way as they race toward something the rest of society considers beyond the pale. In this case, they're racing to produce the world's first human clone. A few years ago, such a contest would have seemed preposterous. But now, three different groups say they have clones in the making. Severino Antinori, an Italian fertility doctor, says his clone will be born first. Dr. Antinori, who became famous in 1994 for helping a 62-year-old woman become pregnant by implanting a donor's fertilized egg in her uterus, says he has a clone pregnancy under way in an undisclosed country. The clone, he says, is a boy, due in early January.
docs.abstract: Robin Marantz Henig Op-Ed article says arguments against human cloning are strikingly similar to ones that were made against in-vitro fertilization 30 years ago; says attitudes toward cloning may change just as those toward in-vitro fertilization have; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: State regulators have proposed a $10,000 fine for Our Lady of Lourdes Medical Center, which gave the wrong infant's body to a funeral home earlier this year. The penalty proposed by the State Department of Health and Senior Services includes $2,500 fines for four separate violations. The hospital has 30 days to contest the fine. A security guard went alone to the hospital's morgue on Sept. 15 to retrieve the body of 10-day-old Robyn Williams, but returned with the body of a stillborn girl. Neither the guard nor the representative of the Potter Quay Funeral Home in Vineland noticed the mistake. A hospital representative could not be reached for comment.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Fine In Case Of Switched Body

docs.abstract: Our Lady of Lourdes Medical Center, Camden, NJ, is fined for giving wrong baby's bond to funeral home (S)
